indicators.justification:
While companies are required to register their beneficial owners (BOs) in the national Slovakia Commercial Register (1), the website does not provide access to this BO information publicly, only to certain government agencies and law enforcement. 
BO information in Slovakia is only available via the Public Sector Partners Register (Register partnerov verejného sektora), or RVPS in short.(2),(3) Therefore, the assessment with regards to the BO information in this indicator was only performed on the RVPS register. 
The register does not hold information about all companies, only those with a highest risk of getting involved in a procurement corruption. Obligation to register BOs rises for companies that receive public funding or conduct business with the government which use public resources in lump sums of EUR 100 000 or more, or EUR 250 000 or more in a calendar year for recurrent operations. (4), (5)
The register allows full open data access via API or offers a search function to users without the need for coding. Simple search offers names of BOs and identifying company information, with more details about BOs available via PDF downloads.

This register meant a significant step forward in the access to information about BOs in Slovakia and has led to several investigations, including the wealth of the Czech prime minister Babis in Slovakia.(6) 
However, according to an analysis performed by Transparency International Slovakia, the BO data in the RVPS register contained a considerable amount of mistakes. The organisation also recommended improving the ability to download the data in bulk or partially for people without API skills. (7)

Several improvements could be made to the amount of data available as well as to their format, and availability in one place. indicators.justification:
A lot of the CSO activity around public procurement followed in the years after the Central Register of Contracts was launched in 2011, initiating a pro-active provision of government information. 
Investigative journalists and CSOs make regular use of the data to monitor that procurement processes adhere to the law (1) or they advocate for certain changes to the current legislation to be made. (2)
